title: AGENTS Guidelines
text: Use 4 spaces indentation; avoid tabs. Prefer snake_case functions variables; R6 class names use PascalCase. Document public functions roxygen2 comments. Write commit messages imperative mood keep concise. edit .Rd automatically generated Roxygen2. use htmltools::JS, instead use tabulatoR::js function going test, use pkgload::load_all() instead installing devtools. Don’t run tests. dependencies bulky. run tests ona capable system.

title: Column Specifications
text: vignette covers define customize columns tabulatoR tables. complete details available column options, refer official Tabulator documentation columns. tabulatoR provides Column() helper function define column specifications map directly Tabulator’s column definition format. Tabulator column options supported Column(). Note: examples vignette show Shiny server code. use Shiny app, place inside server function.

title: Column Specifications
text: default, tabulatoR automatically generate columns data:
code: # Create sample data data <- data.frame(   id = 1:5,   name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Charlie", "Diana", "Eve"),   age = c(28, 34, 23, 45, 31),   department = c("Sales", "Engineering", "Sales", "HR", "Engineering") )  # In your Shiny server function: output$table <- renderTabulatoR({   data }, autoColumns = TRUE)

title: Column Specifications
text: control, define columns explicitly using Column():
code: # In your Shiny server function: output$table <- renderTabulatoR({   data }, columns = c(   Column(title = "ID", field = "id"),   Column(title = "Employee Name", field = "name"),   Column(title = "Age", field = "age"),   Column(title = "Department", field = "department") ), autoColumns = FALSE )

title: Column Specifications
text: Column() function accepts standard Tabulator column options:
code: # Set width explicitly Column(title = "ID", field = "id", width = "60px")  # Control horizontal alignment Column(title = "Name", field = "name", hozAlign = "left") Column(title = "Age", field = "age", hozAlign = "right")  # Make column resizable Column(title = "Department", field = "department", resizable = TRUE)  # Hide a column Column(title = "Internal ID", field = "internal_id", visible = FALSE)

title: Column Specifications
text: Enable editing setting editor editable:
code: # Method 1: Set editor explicitly (editable is automatically TRUE) Column(title = "Name", field = "name", editor = "input")  # Method 2: Set editable = TRUE (Tabulator auto-detects editor type) Column(title = "Age", field = "age", editable = TRUE)  # Method 3: Make all auto-generated columns editable in renderTabulatoR output$table <- renderTabulatoR({   data }, editable = TRUE)

title: Column Specifications
text: tabulatoR supports Tabulator editor types:
code: # Text input editor (single-line) Column(title = "Name", field = "name", editor = "input")  # Number editor with validation Column(   title = "Age",   field = "age",   editor = "number",   editorParams = list(min = 0, max = 120, step = 1) )  # Textarea editor (multi-line text) Column(title = "Notes", field = "notes", editor = "textarea")  # Select dropdown Column(   title = "Department",   field = "department",   editor = "select",   editorParams = list(values = c("Sales", "Engineering", "Marketing", "HR")) )  # Checkbox editor Column(   title = "Active",   field = "active",   editor = "tickCross",   hozAlign = "center" )  # Date editor Column(   title = "Start Date",   field = "start_date",   editor = "date" )  # Read-only column (no editor) Column(title = "ID", field = "id", editable = FALSE)

title: Column Specifications
text: Customize editor behavior editorParams:
code: # Number editor with constraints Column(   title = "Score",   field = "score",   editor = "number",   editorParams = list(     min = 0,     max = 100,     step = 5,     elementAttributes = list(maxlength = "3")   ) )  # Select with custom display values Column(   title = "Priority",   field = "priority",   editor = "select",   editorParams = list(     values = list(       list(label = "Low Priority", value = "low"),       list(label = "Medium Priority", value = "medium"),       list(label = "High Priority", value = "high")     )   ) )

title: Column Specifications
text: Tabulator includes many built-formatters:
code: # Money formatter Column(   title = "Price",   field = "price",   formatter = "money",   formatterParams = list(     decimal = ".",     thousand = ",",     symbol = "$",     precision = 2   ) )  # Tick/Cross for boolean values Column(   title = "Active",   field = "active",   formatter = "tickCross",   hozAlign = "center" )  # Progress bar Column(   title = "Completion",   field = "completion",   formatter = "progress",   formatterParams = list(color = "green") )  # Link formatter Column(   title = "Website",   field = "url",   formatter = "link",   formatterParams = list(target = "_blank") )

title: Column Specifications
text: Create custom cell formatters using js() helper function:
code: # Simple custom formatter Column( title = "Price", field = "price", formatter = js("function(cell) { return '$' + cell.getValue().toFixed(2); }") ) # Conditional formatting Column( title = "Status", field = "status", formatter = js("function(cell) { var value = cell.getValue(); var color = value === 'active' ? 'green' : 'red'; return '' + value + ''; }") ) # Multi-field formatter Column( title = "Full Name", field = "full_name", formatter = js("function(cell) { var data = cell.getData(); return data.first_name + ' ' + data.last_name; }") )

title: Column Specifications
text: Row formatters apply styling logic entire rows based data. specified table level, individual columns:
code: output$table <- renderTabulatoR({   data }, columns = c(   Column(title = "ID", field = "id"),   Column(title = "Name", field = "name"),   Column(title = "Status", field = "status") ), rowFormatter = js("function(row) {   var data = row.getData();    // Highlight active rows in green   if(data.status === 'active') {     row.getElement().style.backgroundColor = '#d4edda';   }    // Highlight inactive rows in red   if(data.status === 'inactive') {     row.getElement().style.backgroundColor = '#f8d7da';   }    // Make high-priority rows bold   if(data.priority === 'high') {     row.getElement().style.fontWeight = 'bold';   } }") )

title: Column Specifications
code: # Zebra striping with custom colors rowFormatter = js("function(row) {   if(row.getIndex() % 2 === 0) {     row.getElement().style.backgroundColor = '#f8f9fa';   } }")  # Highlight rows based on threshold rowFormatter = js("function(row) {   var amount = row.getData().amount;   if(amount > 1000) {     row.getElement().style.backgroundColor = '#fff3cd';     row.getElement().style.borderLeft = '4px solid #ffc107';   } }")  # Disable row interaction based on condition rowFormatter = js("function(row) {   if(row.getData().locked) {     row.getElement().style.opacity = '0.5';     row.getElement().style.pointerEvents = 'none';   } }")

title: Column Specifications
text: Respond cell clicks custom JavaScript:
code: # Simple alert on click Column(   title = "Name",   field = "name",   cellClick = js("function(e, cell) {     alert('Clicked: ' + cell.getValue());   }") )  # Send data back to Shiny Column(   title = "Actions",   field = "id",   cellClick = js("function(e, cell) {     Shiny.setInputValue('clicked_id', cell.getValue(), {priority: 'event'});   }") )

title: Column Specifications
text: Track cells edited:
code: Column(   title = "Name",   field = "name",   editor = "input",   cellEdited = js("function(cell) {     console.log('Cell edited:', cell.getValue());      // Send to Shiny     Shiny.setInputValue('edited_cell', {       field: cell.getField(),       value: cell.getValue(),       row: cell.getData()     }, {priority: 'event'});   }") )

title: Column Specifications
text: Create custom action buttons column using formatter option field = NULL:
code: Column(   title = "Actions",   field = NULL,  # No data field   formatter = js(r'(     (cell) => {       const row = cell.getRow();       const div = document.createElement('div');       div.style.display = 'flex';       div.style.gap = '5px';        // Delete button       const deleteBtn = document.createElement('button');       deleteBtn.textContent = 'Delete';       deleteBtn.className = 'btn btn-danger btn-sm';       deleteBtn.onclick = () => {         if(confirm('Delete this row?')) {           row.delete();         }       };       div.appendChild(deleteBtn);        // Edit button       const editBtn = document.createElement('button');       editBtn.textContent = 'Edit';       editBtn.className = 'btn btn-primary btn-sm';       editBtn.onclick = () => {         Shiny.setInputValue("edit_row", row.getData(), {priority: 'event'});       };       div.appendChild(editBtn);        return div;     }   )') )

title: Column Specifications
text: Validate cell input custom logic:
code: # Email validation Column(   title = "Email",   field = "email",   editor = "input",   validator = js("function(cell, value) {     // Email regex validation     var regex = /^[^\\s@]+@[^\\s@]+\\.[^\\s@]+$/;     return regex.test(value);   }") )  # Age range validation Column(   title = "Age",   field = "age",   editor = "number",   validator = js("function(cell, value) {     return value >= 18 && value <= 100;   }") )

title: Column Specifications
text: ’s comprehensive example combining concepts:
code: # In your Shiny server function: output$advanced_table <- renderTabulatoR({ data.frame( id = 1:5, name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Charlie", "Diana", "Eve"), email = c("alice@example.com", "bob@example.com", "charlie@example.com", "diana@example.com", "eve@example.com"), age = c(28, 34, 23, 45, 31), salary = c(65000, 85000, 55000, 95000, 72000), department = c("Sales", "Engineering", "Sales", "HR", "Engineering"), status = c("active", "active", "inactive", "active", "active"), completion = c(85, 92, 45, 78, 88) ) }, columns = c( Column(title = "ID", field = "id", width = "60px", editable = FALSE), Column( title = "Name", field = "name", editor = "input", cellEdited = js("function(cell) { console.log('Name updated:', cell.getValue()); }") ), Column( title = "Email", field = "email", editor = "input", validator = js("function(cell, value) { return /^[^\\s@]+@[^\\s@]+\\.[^\\s@]+$/.test(value); }") ), Column( title = "Age", field = "age", editor = "number", editorParams = list(min = 18, max = 100), hozAlign = "right" ), Column( title = "Salary", field = "salary", formatter = "money", formatterParams = list(symbol = "$", thousand = ",", precision = 0), hozAlign = "right" ), Column( title = "Department", field = "department", editor = "select", editorParams = list(values = c("Sales", "Engineering", "Marketing", "HR")) ), Column( title = "Status", field = "status", formatter = js("function(cell) { var value = cell.getValue(); var color = value === 'active' ? 'green' : 'red'; return '' + value + ''; }") ), Column( title = "Progress", field = "completion", formatter = "progress", formatterParams = list(color = "blue") ), Column( title = "Actions", field = NULL, formatter = js(r'( (cell) => { const btn = document.createElement('button'); btn.textContent = 'View'; btn.className = 'btn btn-sm btn-primary'; btn.onclick = () => { Shiny.setInputValue("view_employee", cell.getData(), {priority: 'event'}); }; return btn; } )') ) ), rowFormatter = js("function(row) { if(row.getData().status === 'inactive') { row.getElement().style.backgroundColor = '#f8d7da'; } if(row.getData().completion > 90) { row.getElement().style.borderLeft = '4px solid #28a745'; } }"), autoColumns = FALSE )

title: Column Specifications
text: Tabulator Column Documentation Tabulator Formatters Tabulator Editors Tabulator Events

title: Getting Started with tabulatoR
text: tabulatoR brings powerful Tabulator JavaScript library Shiny applications, providing interactive, customizable data tables minimal code. vignette guide creating basic tables implementing editing functionality.

title: Getting Started with tabulatoR
text: Let’s start basic example using built-mtcars dataset: creates fully functional table auto-generated columns. default, renderTabulatoR() sets autoColumns = TRUE, automatically creates columns based dataframe structure.
code: library(shiny) library(tabulatoR)  ui <- fluidPage(   titlePanel("Basic Tabulator Table"),   tabulatoROutput("my_table", height = "500px") )  server <- function(input, output, session) {   output$my_table <- renderTabulatoR({     # Use a subset of mtcars for clarity     data <- head(mtcars, 10)     data   }) }  shinyApp(ui, server)

previous_headings: Introduction > Creating a Simple Static Table
title: Getting Started with tabulatoR
text: control table’s appearance behavior, can define columns explicitly using Column() helper function:
code: ui <- fluidPage(   titlePanel("Customized Table"),   tabulatoROutput("cars_table", height = "500px") )  server <- function(input, output, session) {   output$cars_table <- renderTabulatoR({     x = head(mtcars, 10)     x$rowname = row.names(x)     x   },   columns = c(     Column(title = "Car Model", field = "rowname"),     Column(title = "MPG", field = "mpg", hozAlign = "center"),     Column(title = "Cylinders", field = "cyl", hozAlign = "center"),     Column(title = "Horsepower", field = "hp", hozAlign = "right"),     Column(title = "Weight", field = "wt", hozAlign = "right")   ),   autoColumns = FALSE,   editable = FALSE   ) }  shinyApp(ui, server)

title: Getting Started with tabulatoR
text: One tabulatoR’s key features enabling inline editing. Let’s create editable table users can modify values directly: example demonstrates several editor types: editor = "input": Basic text input Name column editor = "number": Numeric input Age column editor = "select": Dropdown selection Department column predefined values editable = FALSE: ID column read-Note table allows editing, changes yet persisted back reactive data. ’ll address next section.
code: ui <- fluidPage(   titlePanel("Editable Table Example"),    fluidRow(     column(       width = 8,       tabulatoROutput("editable_table", height = "500px")     ),     column(       width = 4,       h4("Table Data"),       verbatimTextOutput("current_data")     )   ) )  server <- function(input, output, session) {   # Store table data in a reactive value   table_data <- reactiveVal(data.frame(     id = 1:5,     name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Charlie", "Diana", "Eve"),     age = c(25, 30, 35, 28, 32),     department = c("Sales", "Engineering", "Marketing", "Sales", "Engineering"),     stringsAsFactors = FALSE   ))    output$editable_table <- renderTabulatoR({     table_data()   },   columns = c(     Column(title = "ID", field = "id", editable = FALSE),     Column(title = "Name", field = "name", editor = "input"),     Column(title = "Age", field = "age", editor = "number"),     Column(       title = "Department",       field = "department",       editor = "select",       editorParams = list(values = c("Sales", "Engineering", "Marketing", "HR"))     )   ),   autoColumns = FALSE   )    # Display the current table data   output$current_data <- renderPrint({     table_data()   }) }  shinyApp(ui, server)

what: Handling Table Events with Shiny Observers
title: Getting Started with tabulatoR
text: make editable table truly interactive, need respond user actions. tabulatoR sends table events back Shiny single reactive input.

previous_headings: Introduction > Handling Table Events with Shiny Observers
title: Getting Started with tabulatoR
text: ’s capture cell edits update data:
code: ui <- fluidPage(   titlePanel("Interactive Editable Table"),    fluidRow(     column(       width = 8,       tabulatoROutput("interactive_table", height = "500px")     ),     column(       width = 4,       h4("Latest Event"),       verbatimTextOutput("latest_event"),       h4("Current Data"),       verbatimTextOutput("current_data")     )   ) )  server <- function(input, output, session) {   # Initialize reactive data   table_data <- reactiveVal(data.frame(     id = 1:5,     name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Charlie", "Diana", "Eve"),     age = c(25, 30, 35, 28, 32),     status = c("active", "active", "inactive", "active", "inactive"),     notes = c("", "Team lead", "", "New hire", ""),     stringsAsFactors = FALSE   ))    output$interactive_table <- renderTabulatoR({     table_data()   },   columns = c(     Column(title = "ID", field = "id", editable = FALSE, width = "60px"),     Column(title = "Name", field = "name", editor = "input"),     Column(title = "Age", field = "age", editor = "number",            editorParams = list(min = 18, max = 100)),     Column(       title = "Status",       field = "status",       editor = "select",       editorParams = list(values = c("active", "inactive", "pending"))     ),     Column(title = "Notes", field = "notes", editor = "textarea")   ),   autoColumns = FALSE   )    # Handle table events   observeEvent(input$interactive_table, {     event <- input$interactive_table      # Check if this is a cellEdited event     if (!is.null(event$action) && event$action == "cellEdited") {       # Update the data       current_data <- table_data()       current_data[event$index, event$field] <- event$value       table_data(current_data)     }   })    # Display latest event for debugging   output$latest_event <- renderPrint({     input$interactive_table   })    # Display current data   output$current_data <- renderPrint({     table_data()   }) }  shinyApp(ui, server)

previous_headings: Introduction > Handling Table Events with Shiny Observers
title: Getting Started with tabulatoR
text: user interacts table, tabulatoR sends event objects Shiny via input$<table_id>. event structure includes: action: type event (e.g., "cellEdited", "rowAdded", "rowDeleted") index: row index (1-based, matching R conventions) field: column field name edited value: new value editing row: complete row data (row-level events)

previous_headings: Introduction > Handling Table Events with Shiny Observers
title: Getting Started with tabulatoR
text: typical patterns handling table events:

previous_headings: Introduction > Handling Table Events with Shiny Observers > Common Observer Patterns
title: Getting Started with tabulatoR
code: observeEvent(input$my_table, {   event <- input$my_table    if (!is.null(event$action) && event$action == "cellEdited") {     # Update your reactive data     current_data <- table_data()     current_data[event$index, event$field] <- event$value     table_data(current_data)      # Optional: Save to database, log changes, etc.     message(sprintf("Cell edited: Row %d, Field %s, New value: %s",                     event$index, event$field, event$value))   } })

previous_headings: Introduction > Handling Table Events with Shiny Observers > Common Observer Patterns
title: Getting Started with tabulatoR
code: observeEvent(input$my_table, {   event <- input$my_table    if (!is.null(event$action)) {     if (event$action == "cellEdited") {       # Handle cell edit       message(sprintf("Row %d: %s changed to %s",                       event$index, event$field, event$value))     } else if (event$action == "rowAdded") {       # Handle new row       message("New row added")     } else if (event$action == "rowDeleted") {       # Handle row deletion       message("Row deleted")     }   } })

previous_headings: Introduction > Handling Table Events with Shiny Observers > Common Observer Patterns
title: Getting Started with tabulatoR
code: observeEvent(input$my_table, {   event <- input$my_table    if (!is.null(event$action) && event$action == "cellEdited") {     # Validate the new value     if (event$field == "age" && (event$value < 18 || event$value > 100)) {       showNotification("Age must be between 18 and 100", type = "error")       # Revert the cell to its previous value       tabulatorRevertField("my_table", event$index, event$field)       return()     }      # Update data if validation passes     current_data <- table_data()     current_data[event$index, event$field] <- event$value     table_data(current_data)   } })

title: Getting Started with tabulatoR
text: vignette covered basics creating editing tables tabulatoR. advanced features, see: Advanced Editing: Row addition/deletion, bulk operations, CRUD integration JavaScript Customization: Custom formatters, cell renderers, event handlers Spreadsheet Mode: Excel-like functionality renderSpreadsheet() Styling Theming: Customizing table appearance complete documentation available options, refer Tabulator documentation.

title: javascript
text: tabulatoR provides lightweight R interface powerful Tabulator JavaScript library. Unlike traditional htmlwidgets-based packages, tabulatoR uses custom Shiny output binding direct JSON serialization, giving clean, predictable output full access Tabulator’s extensive API.

what: Why Tabulator Works Well with R
title: javascript
text: Tabulator JavaScript library uses standard JSON object render interactive tables. Since Tabulator specification essentially named list (JSON object), makes Tabulator ideal candidate R wrapper. R’s data structures serialize cleanly exact format Tabulator expects, requiring minimal transformation. ’s example Tabulator documentation showing typical table configuration: Tabulator JSON specification: Equivalent R list() format: Notice one--one correspondence: - JSON objects {} → R named lists list() - JSON arrays [] → R lists list() - JSON booleans true/false → R logicals TRUE/FALSE - JSON strings numbers remain natural mapping means tabulatoR can pass R configurations directly Tabulator minimal overhead.
code: {   "data": [     {"name": "Alice", "age": 30, "city": "NYC"},     {"name": "Bob", "age": 25, "city": "LA"}   ],   "columns": [     {"title": "Name", "field": "name", "sorter": "string"},     {"title": "Age", "field": "age", "editor": "number", "validator": "min:0"},     {"title": "City", "field": "city", "editor": "input"}   ],   "layout": "fitColumns",   "pagination": true,   "paginationSize": 10 } list(   data = list(     list(name = "Alice", age = 30, city = "NYC"),     list(name = "Bob", age = 25, city = "LA")   ),   columns = list(     list(title = "Name", field = "name", sorter = "string"),     list(title = "Age", field = "age", editor = "number", validator = "min:0"),     list(title = "City", field = "city", editor = "input")   ),   layout = "fitColumns",   pagination = TRUE,   paginationSize = 10 )

title: javascript
text: integration consists three main components: R functions (render.R) - renderTabulatoR() renderSpreadsheet() serialize data configuration JSON Custom Shiny binding (tabulatoR.js) - Handles table creation, updates, event routing UI manipulation functions (proxy.R) - Allow R invoke methods existing tables Data flow:
code: R (renderTabulatoR)   → JSON payload   → Shiny output binding   → Creates Tabulator instance   → User interaction triggers events   → Events send data back to R via Shiny.setInputValue()   → R observes input$tableId and reacts

title: javascript
text: main function renderTabulatoR(): happens behind scenes: data.frame converted list named lists (object format JavaScript) Column definitions options serialized JSON custom output binding receives payload new Tabulator instance created: new Tabulator(el, options) table reference stored globally: window[el.id] = table
code: library(shiny) library(tabulatoR)  ui <- fluidPage(   tab_source(),  # Load Tabulator CSS/JS from CDN   tabulatorOutput("myTable") )  server <- function(input, output, session) {   output$myTable <- renderTabulatoR(     mtcars,     columns = c(       Column("Model", "model"),       Column("MPG", "mpg", .editor = "number"),       Column("Cylinders", "cyl", .editor = "number")     ),     autoColumns = FALSE,     layout = "fitColumns"   ) }  shinyApp(ui, server)

title: javascript
text: Event listeners connect JavaScript interactions back R. tabulatoR provides default handlers common events, can override add custom ones.

previous_headings: Overview: How tabulatoR Wraps Tabulator.js > Event Listeners
title: javascript
text: events automatically registered sensible defaults: cellClick - Captures: field, value, row data, row index cellEdited - Captures: field, value, old_value, row data, row index validationFailed - Captures: field, value, validation failure info rowAdded - Captures: new row data index rowDeleted - Captures: deleted row data index Using default events R:
code:
server <- function(input, output, session) {   output$myTable <- renderTabulatoR(mtcars)    # Listen to default cellEdited event   observeEvent(input$myTable, {     event_data <- input$myTable      cat("Cell edited:
")     cat("  Field:", event_data$field, "
")     cat("  New value:", event_data$value, "
")     cat("  Old value:", event_data$old_value, "
")     cat("  Row index:", event_data$index, "
")   }) }

previous_headings: Overview: How tabulatoR Wraps Tabulator.js > Event Listeners
title: javascript
text: Override defaults add new events using events parameter js() wrapper: works: js() function wraps JavaScript <js>...</js> tags JSON serialization, becomes string JavaScript binding detects tags via parseJSValue() string evaluated back executable function: eval(code) event fires, function processes data returned object sent R via Shiny.setInputValue() use js() instead toJSON()? might wonder tabulatoR uses js() wrapper approach instead R’s standard jsonlite::toJSON() similar serialization methods. reason nested formulas custom functions don’t serialize properly couple layers traditional JSON serialization. deeply nested Tabulator configurations—like formatters within column definitions, validators custom logic, complex event handlers reference functions—standard JSON serialization fails preserve executable function references. js() approach allows custom functions formulas passed deeply nested structures properly reconstructed JavaScript side. isn’t ergonomic approach R perspective, gives full access Tabulator’s powerful JavaScript API without limitations nesting depth complexity.
code: output$myTable <- renderTabulatoR(   mtcars,   events = list(     # Custom cellEdited handler     cellEdited = js("       function(cell) {         return {           field: cell.getField(),           newValue: cell.getValue(),           oldValue: cell.getOldValue(),           rowIndex: cell.getRow().getPosition(),           customInfo: 'Modified by user'         };       }     "),      # Row selection tracking     rowSelectionChanged = js("       function(data, rows) {         return {           selectedCount: rows.length,           selectedIds: rows.map(r => r.getData().id)         };       }     "),      # Cell context menu     cellContext = js("       function(e, cell) {         e.preventDefault();         return {           field: cell.getField(),           value: cell.getValue(),           position: { x: e.clientX, y: e.clientY }         };       }     ")   ) )

previous_headings: Overview: How tabulatoR Wraps Tabulator.js > Event Listeners
title: javascript
text: can register handlers Tabulator event. Common ones include: Data events: dataLoaded, dataChanged, dataFiltered, dataSorted Cell events: cellClick, cellDblClick, cellEdited, cellMouseEnter Row events: rowClick, rowAdded, rowDeleted, rowMoved, rowSelected Column events: columnMoved, columnResized, columnVisibilityChanged Validation: validationFailed Editing: dataEdited, editableCheck

what: Invoking Methods from R (UI Manipulation Functions)
title: javascript
text: Unlike traditional Shiny “proxy” objects maintain synchronized state R JavaScript, tabulatoR provides UI manipulation functions directly invoke methods client-side Tabulator instance. functions use session$sendCustomMessage() send commands JavaScript, modifying table without re-rendering maintaining server-side copy table state.

previous_headings: Overview: How tabulatoR Wraps Tabulator.js > Invoking Methods from R (UI Manipulation Functions)
title: javascript
text: ’re coming popular table packages like DT reactable, may accustomed using “proxy” objects decouple rendered output UI state. implementations, proxy maintains server-side representation stays synchronized client. tabulatoR takes different approach: ’s decoupling renderTabulatoR() output binding UI. Instead, provide simple wrapper functions send messages directly existing Tabulator instance browser. means: server-side state synchronization proxy object create manage Direct method invocation client-side table Lighter weight straightforward simply call functions like tabulatorAddRow() tabulatorRemoveRow(), send commands manipulate UI table directly.

previous_headings: Overview: How tabulatoR Wraps Tabulator.js > Invoking Methods from R (UI Manipulation Functions)
title: javascript
text: Behind scenes:
code: server <- function(input, output, session) {   output$myTable <- renderTabulatoR(mtcars)    observeEvent(input$addRowBtn, {     new_row <- data.frame(       model = "New Car",       mpg = 25,       cyl = 4,       stringsAsFactors = FALSE     )      # Add to bottom (default)     tabulatorAddRow("myTable", new_row)      # Or add to top     tabulatorAddRow("myTable", new_row, add_to = "top")   }) } R: tabulatorAddRow("myTable", data, "bottom")   → session$sendCustomMessage("tabulator-add-data", list(id = "myTable", data = data, add_to = "bottom"))   → JS: Shiny.addCustomMessageHandler receives message   → Finds table: document.getElementById("myTable")   → Calls: table.addData(message.data, message.add_to)

previous_headings: Overview: How tabulatoR Wraps Tabulator.js > Invoking Methods from R (UI Manipulation Functions)
title: javascript
code: # Remove row at index 5 tabulatorRemoveRow("myTable", index = 5)

previous_headings: Overview: How tabulatoR Wraps Tabulator.js > Invoking Methods from R (UI Manipulation Functions)
title: javascript
code: # Replace entire table with new data tabulatorReplaceData("myTable", new_data_frame)

previous_headings: Overview: How tabulatoR Wraps Tabulator.js > Invoking Methods from R (UI Manipulation Functions)
title: javascript
code: observeEvent(input$myTable, {   edited <- input$myTable    # Validation check   if (edited$value < 0) {     showNotification("Negative values not allowed!", type = "error")      # Revert the cell to its previous value     tabulatorRevertField(       "myTable",       index = edited$index,       field = edited$field     )   } })

previous_headings: Overview: How tabulatoR Wraps Tabulator.js > Invoking Methods from R (UI Manipulation Functions)
title: javascript
text: tables created renderSpreadsheet():
code: # Replace spreadsheet data spreadsheetSetData("mySheet", new_data)  # Clear all cells spreadsheetClearSheet("mySheet")  # Get current spreadsheet data (triggers input$mySheet_data) spreadsheetGetData("mySheet")  observeEvent(input$mySheet_data, {   current_data <- input$mySheet_data   # Process or save the data })

title: javascript
text: advanced use cases, can access Tabulator instance directly JavaScript: use browser console JavaScript:
code: output$myTable <- renderTabulatoR(   mtcars,   .opts = list(     # Any Tabulator option works here     pagination = TRUE,     paginationSize = 10,     groupBy = "cyl",     movableRows = TRUE,     selectable = "highlight"   ) ) // Access the table (if table id is "myTable") const table = window.myTable;  // Call any Tabulator method table.deselectRow(); table.setFilter("mpg", ">", 20); table.download("csv", "data.csv");

what: Complete Example: Editable Table with Validation
title: javascript
text: example demonstrates full lifecycle: initial render, event handling, validation, UI manipulation via table methods.
code:
ui <- fluidPage(   tab_source(theme = "tabulator_bootstrap5"),   actionButton("addRow", "Add Row"),   actionButton("getData", "Get Current Data"),   tabulatorOutput("editableTable"),   verbatimTextOutput("debugInfo") )  server <- function(input, output, session) {   # Reactive to store current valid data   table_data <- reactiveVal(mtcars[1:5, ])    output$editableTable <- renderTabulatoR(     table_data(),     columns = c(       Column("Model", "model"),       Column("MPG", "mpg", .editor = "number", .validator = "min:0"),       Column("Cylinders", "cyl", .editor = "list",              .editorParams = list(values = c(4, 6, 8)))     ),     events = list(       cellEdited = js("         function(cell) {           return {             field: cell.getField(),             value: cell.getValue(),             old_value: cell.getOldValue(),             index: cell.getRow().getPosition()           };         }       "),       validationFailed = js("         function(cell, value, validators) {           return {             field: cell.getField(),             invalidValue: value,             validators: validators           };         }       ")     ),     layout = "fitColumns"   )    # Handle valid edits   observeEvent(input$editableTable, {     edit <- input$editableTable      # Update our reactive data store     current <- table_data()     current[edit$index, edit$field] <- edit$value     table_data(current)      output$debugInfo <- renderPrint({       cat("Valid edit:
")       cat("  Row:", edit$index, "
")       cat("  Field:", edit$field, "
")       cat("  Old:", edit$old_value, "
")       cat("  New:", edit$value, "
")     })   })    # Handle validation failures   observeEvent(input$editableTable_validationFailed, {     fail <- input$editableTable_validationFailed      showNotification(       paste0("Invalid value for ", fail$field, ": ", fail$invalidValue),       type = "error"     )      # Revert to old value     tabulatorRevertField(       "editableTable",       index = fail$index,       field = fail$field     )   })    # Add new row   observeEvent(input$addRow, {     new_row <- data.frame(       model = "New Car",       mpg = 20,       cyl = 4,       stringsAsFactors = FALSE     )     tabulatorAddRow("editableTable", new_row, add_to = "bottom")   }) }  shinyApp(ui, server)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Orr K (2026). tabulatoR: Tabulator Integration Shiny Applications. R package version 0.0.0.9002, https://kent-orr.github.io/tabulatoR/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {tabulatoR: Tabulator Integration for Shiny Applications},   author = {Kent Orr},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9002},   url = {https://kent-orr.github.io/tabulatoR/}, }

title: tabulatoR - Tabulator Integration for Shiny
text: tabulatoR R package brings powerful Tabulator JavaScript library Shiny applications. ’s lightweight, extensible wrapper designed interactive, highly customizable data tables R.

title: tabulatoR - Tabulator Integration for Shiny
text: Column-first design – Define columns behavior, formatting, interactivity. Direct JavaScript integration – Use custom JS inline limitless customization. Shiny-ready – Built ground reactive, event-driven apps. Lightweight & flexible – load need, without heavy dependencies.

title: tabulatoR - Tabulator Integration for Shiny
code: # Install from GitHub # remotes::install_github("yourusername/tabulatoR")  library(shiny) library(tabulatoR)  ui <- fluidPage(   tabulatorOutput("my_table") )  server <- function(input, output, session) {   output$my_table <- renderTabulator({     tabulator(iris, columns = list(       list(title = "Sepal.Length", field = "Sepal.Length", sorter = "number"),       list(title = "Species", field = "Species", sorter = "string")     ))   }) }  shinyApp(ui, server)

title: Define a Tabulator Column — Column
text: helper function constructs Tabulator column definition list suitable use renderTabulatoR(). provides concise set useful column configuration parameters Shiny applications allowing full access Tabulator's extensive API via ... .opts.

title: Define a Tabulator Column — Column
code: Column(   title,   field,   visible = TRUE,   hozAlign = NULL,   width = NULL,   resizable = NULL,   editable = FALSE,   editor = NULL,   editorParams = NULL,   formatter = NULL,   formatterParams = NULL,   cellClick = NULL,   cellEdited = NULL,   ...,   .opts = list() )

title: Define a Tabulator Column — Column
text: title column title display table header. field field name data corresponding column. visible Logical. Whether column visible. Default TRUE. hozAlign Horizontal text alignment cells ("left", "center", "right"). width fixed column width (e.g., "150px" "20%"). resizable Logical. Whether user can resize column. editable Logical. TRUE, cells editable. set TRUE editor NULL, Tabulator guesses editor (editor = TRUE). editor Editor type ("input", "number", etc.) JS function via js(). Supplying parameter implicitly enables editing. editorParams list parameters passed editor. formatter Formatter name JS function (use js()). formatterParams list parameters passed formatter. cellClick JS function triggered cell clicked (use js()). cellEdited JS function triggered cell edited (use js()). ... Additional named Tabulator column options. .opts named list column options can reused programmatically. Values ... override matching keys .opts.

title: Define a Tabulator Column — Column
text: named list representing single column definition.

title: Define a Tabulator Column — Column
text: full list column options, see Tabulator documentation. JavaScript callbacks (cellClick formatter) must wrapped using js() package interpreted executable functions browser. Supplying editor implicitly enables editing. editable = TRUE editor provided, Tabulator attempts guess editor (editor = TRUE).

what: Render a Tabulator Spreadsheet in Shiny — renderSpreadsheet
title: Render a Tabulator Spreadsheet in Shiny — renderSpreadsheet
text: Creates reactive Tabulator spreadsheet widget use Shiny applications. Spreadsheet mode provides Excel-like interface grid-based editing, arrow key navigation, clipboard support. function uses column definitions provide real column headers data.frame matrix column names, rather generic , B, C labels. Data stored objects (named lists) allows field-based access simpler CRUD operations. thin wrapper around Tabulator's spreadsheet mode. complete documentation available options features, see official Tabulator documentation: https://tabulator.info/docs/6.3/spreadsheet

title: Render a Tabulator Spreadsheet in Shiny — renderSpreadsheet
code: renderSpreadsheet(   expr,   editable = TRUE,   columnDefinition = NULL,   selectableRange = FALSE,   clipboardPasteAction = "replace",   events = NULL,   options = list(),   ...,   .opts = list(),   env = parent.frame(),   quoted = FALSE )

title: Render a Tabulator Spreadsheet in Shiny — renderSpreadsheet
text: expr reactive expression returns data.frame matrix. editable Logical. TRUE (default), cells can edited. columnDefinition list defining default properties columns. example, list(editor = "input", validator = "numeric"). See https://tabulator.info/docs/6.3/columns column options. selectableRange Logical. TRUE, enables range selection mouse/keyboard. See https://tabulator.info/docs/6.3/select#range clipboardPasteAction Character. Action take pasting data. Options: "replace" (default) "update". See https://tabulator.info/docs/6.3/clipboard events named list JS events sent back Shiny input values. See https://tabulator.info/docs/6.3/events available events. options named list additional Tabulator options customize spreadsheet. Tabulator configuration options supported. See https://tabulator.info/docs/6.3/options ... Additional named elements include payload passed front-end. .opts named list additional payload entries, useful programmatic inclusion. Elements ... override matching keys .opts. env environment evaluate expr. quoted Logical. expr already quoted? , quoted.

title: Render a Tabulator Spreadsheet in Shiny — renderSpreadsheet
text: function returns list serialized passed Tabulator output binding.

title: Render a Tabulator Spreadsheet in Shiny — renderSpreadsheet
text: Spreadsheet mode differs standard table mode several ways: Column headers display actual data.frame/matrix column names Data stored objects field names easier access Double-click cell enter edit mode (press Enter) Use arrow keys navigate cells Press Tab move next cell Built-support copy/paste operations (Ctrl+C / Ctrl+V) use features like pagination, grouping, tree structures editTriggerEvent set "dblclick" default smoother navigation. allows click cells select use arrow keys navigate without accidentally entering edit mode. JavaScript callbacks (event handlers) must wrapped using js() package interpreted executable functions browser.

title: Render a Tabulator Spreadsheet in Shiny — renderSpreadsheet
code: if (interactive()) {   library(shiny)    ui <- fluidPage(     spreadsheetOutput("sheet")   )    server <- function(input, output, session) {     output$sheet <- renderSpreadsheet(       head(mtcars),       editable = TRUE,       selectableRange = TRUE     )   }    shinyApp(ui, server) }

what: Render a Tabulator Table in Shiny — renderTabulatoR
title: Render a Tabulator Table in Shiny — renderTabulatoR
text: Creates reactive Tabulator table widget use Shiny applications. Returns function outputs JSON-serializable payload consumed custom tabulatoR JavaScript output binding. thin wrapper around Tabulator. complete documentation available options features, see official Tabulator documentation: https://tabulator.info/docs/6.3

title: Render a Tabulator Table in Shiny — renderTabulatoR
code: renderTabulatoR(   expr,   columns = c(),   layout = "fitColumns",   autoColumns = TRUE,   editable = TRUE,   events = NULL,   ...,   .opts = list(),   env = parent.frame(),   quoted = FALSE )

title: Render a Tabulator Table in Shiny — renderTabulatoR
text: expr reactive expression returns data.frame. columns array (c(...)) list column definitions Tabulator. element must list representing column config (e.g., list(field = "name", editable = TRUE)). lists coerced unnamed vector ensure JSON serializes array. See https://tabulator.info/docs/6.3/columns column options. layout string defining overall table layout. See https://tabulator.info/docs/6.3/layout autoColumns Logical. TRUE, columns auto-generated data. Set FALSE supplying custom column definitions. editable Logical. TRUE, cells can editable. Pair editor parameter columns. events named list JS events sent back Shiny input values. See https://tabulator.info/docs/6.3/events available events. ... Additional named elements include payload passed front-end. .opts named list additional payload entries, useful programmatic inclusion. Elements ... override matching keys .opts. env environment evaluate expr. quoted Logical. expr already quoted? , quoted. options named list additional Tabulator options (e.g. pagination, sorting, filtering). Tabulator configuration options supported. See https://tabulator.info/docs/6.3/options

title: Render a Tabulator Table in Shiny — renderTabulatoR
text: function returns list serialized passed Tabulator output binding.

title: Render a Tabulator Table in Shiny — renderTabulatoR
text: JavaScript callbacks (cellClick formatter) must wrapped using js() package interpreted executable functions browser. spreadsheet functionality, see renderSpreadsheet().

what: Set data in a Tabulator spreadsheet — spreadsheetSetData

text: Programmatically loads data existing Tabulator spreadsheet Shiny app. function sends message JavaScript binding set spreadsheet data without re-rendering entire widget. function automatically converts data.frames matrices object format (list named lists) used Tabulator spreadsheets column definitions. function calls Tabulator's setData() method. information, see: https://tabulator.info/docs/6.3/data#array

text: function converts data object format row named list field names matching data.frame column names. allows data accessed field name rather position.

title: Set data in a Tabulator spreadsheet — spreadsheetSetData
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # In a Shiny server function: observeEvent(input$load_data_btn, {   new_data <- data.frame(     A = 1:10,     B = 11:20,     C = 21:30   )   spreadsheetSetData("my_spreadsheet", new_data) }) } # }

title: Revert a cell to its previous value — tabulatorRevertField
text: function calls Tabulator's cell.restoreOldValue() method, reverts cell value recent edit.

title: Revert a cell to its previous value — tabulatorRevertField
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # In a Shiny server function: observeEvent(input$my_table, {   event <- input$my_table    if (event$action == "cellEdited" && event$value < 0) {     # Revert negative values     tabulatorRevertField("my_table", event$index, event$field)   } }) } # }
